We also visit Khogno Khan mountain, a small temple at its base. This region is also renowned for its birdlife, including steppe eagles. Accommodation: Ger camp

In the morning, we drive for three hours (125mi/200km) to Khustain Nuruu National Park, famous for the re-introduction of Mongolia’s wild horse. The Przewalski’s horse (or takhi horse) almost became extinct, but thanks to the efforts of several Mongolian and international organisations, these magnificent wild horses now roam the steppes of the park. We visit the Project Information Centre and take a guided hike to see the wild horses. Accommodation: Ger camp

After breakfast, we drive back to Ulaanbaatar city. You have the afternoon free to relax or explore the city. In the evening, we have the option to see a live performance of traditional Mongolian song and dance. Performed by the Tumen Ekh dance troupe, we see throat singers, contortionists and Tsam dancers. Total driving: Approximately 130mi (210km), four hours Accommodation: Bayangol Hotel (or similar)

In the morning, we fly to Olgii in western Mongolia, from where we drive offroad for about an hour to Sagsai village. Here, we visit a Kazakh family home. We spend the day seeing how they go about daily life, taking care of and milking the cows, goats and sheep. We can also sample their traditional food and taste homemade yak cheese and yogurt. This is a great opportunity to understand the life of a nomadic family and to experience their friendliness and hospitality. In the afternoon, we return to Olgii and stay overnight at a ger camp. Accommodation: Ger camp

Today we attend the Eagle Festival. For the first day of the festival, we see the competition for the best Kazakh costume, horse racing and archery. In the evening, we enjoy a cultural performance in the local theatre. Accommodation: Ger camp

Today we have another chance to witness the competitions and events of the Eagle Festival. We can see a demonstration from the eagles and their hunters, a camel race and the lively sport of kukhbar (in which two horseback riders wrestle over the possession of a goat skin). After enjoying the festivities, we return to camp for dinner. Accommodation: Ger camp

After breakfast, we transfer to the airport for a mid-morning flight to Ulaanbaatar, arriving midday. We transfer to the hotel and freshen up before a light lunch. This afternoon is free for last-minute sightseeing or souvenir shopping around UB – cashmere, leather goods and traditional handicrafts are all good options and the guide can recommend the best places to go for these. Night owls may want to sample the Ulaanbaatar nightlife! Accommodation: Bayangol Hotel (or similar)

The tour ends after breakfast today and we begin our return journeys home, full of tales and magnificent photos to share. If you aren’t ready for the adventure to end, speak to your sales representative about our range of extension options.

tourName: Western Mongolia tour, the Altai mountains & eagles
placesVisited: Homestays with eagle hunters, Kazakh embroidery lesson, Eagle Festival, urban city walking tour of Ulaanbaatar, landscapes and communities of Western Mongolia
generalInfo:
Discover the raw, windswept beauty of Mongolia’s far west on this cultural journey, anchored by a locally hosted eagle festival, genuine encounters with Kazakh eagle hunters, and the breathtaking wilderness of the Altai Mountains.

This is a slow-travel, small-group experience that takes you deep into the heart of Bayan-Ölgii Province—where the Kazakh people, Mongolia’s largest ethnic minority, have long made their home. With a population of over 100,000, the Kazakhs of western Mongolia maintain a distinct cultural identity shaped by centuries of tradition and the formidable terrain of the Altai range.

More than just a visit, this journey offers the chance to truly engage with the people and places that define the region. You’ll travel through stark yet majestic landscapes, spend time with eagle hunters as they go about their daily routines, and take part in one of the region’s celebrated eagle festivals—where Kazakh heritage is proudly displayed through competitive eagle flights, traditional music, horsemanship, and community pride.

The itinerary also includes time in the provincial capital of Ölgii—a dynamic yet often overlooked part of life in the west—providing insight into how Kazakh culture continues to evolve in modern Mongolia.

This adventure is curated and led by a small, purpose-driven travel company that works hand-in-hand with local families and communities, with each experience shaped with the intent to support rural livelihoods while maintaining cultural integrity. The result is a more meaningful, grounded journey that benefits those you meet along the way.

If you’re drawn to authentic cultural immersion and wild, remote landscapes, this is a journey you can either join as part of a small group or customise to fit your own travel pace and interests. While the eagle festivals are held in autumn—typically September and October—this region is captivating year-round for those seeking a window into one of Mongolia’s most resilient and culturally rich communities.

dayInfo.description: ULAANBAATAR - Final arrival day into Ulaanbaatar: Ulaanbaatar (UB) maintains a strong Mongolian identity of its own and has a ‘frontier’ feel and vibrancy. It is a city well-worth exploring and, for those interested, we include a free walking tour for a more local introduction

WESTERN MONGOLIA: Altai Tavan Bogd National Park (Mountains): Fly out to western Mongolia to the provincial capital of Ulgii you will meet your EL team before you then travel to the picturesque Baga Oigor River Valley. Although a very rough road, in this extraordinary region, the vast and timeless landscapes—glaciated peaks, alpine lakes, and hidden valleys—invite deep reflection and a reconsideration of life’s priorities. On the second day, you'll embark on a journey (part drive and hike, be prepared for some very bad roads) to the President's Ovoo in Altai Tavan Bogd National Park. . As you make your way through stunning mountain landscapes, you'll eventually reach the ovoo, a significant cultural and spiritual site offering panoramic views of the surrounding region.

Altai Tavan Bogd National Park (Lakes): Continue to spectacular alpine lakes of Khoton and Khurgan Nuur. Altai Tavan Bogd National Park can be divided into two regions, the Tavan Bogd Mountains in the northwest and the Lakes Region to the southeast. The lakes are fed by glacial melt and annual snowfall and form the headwaters of the Khovd River. We'll keep the remaining days flexible, but here's an idea you can discuss with your trip assistant: Consider a day hike to the Baga Turgen Waterfall. The round-trip trek from Khoton Nuur to the waterfall in Western Mongolia spans approximately 16 to 18 kilometers, featuring a mix of gradual and moderate ascents with a total elevation gain of 400 to 500 meters if hiking directly from the lake. If you'd prefer a shorter hike, a vehicle transfer can be arranged for part of the journey. On Sept 10, you will return to Ulgii. This stop is necessary because the drive from Khoton/Khurgan Nuur to Altai soum, where you’ll spend time with an eagle hunting family, is too long to complete in one day. Plus, this gives you the opportunity to enjoy a hot shower and recharge before continuing the journey.

Altai: Head to the small community of Altai district - in the south of Bayan Ulgii Province. Altai is a remarkable location and is the winter pasture of Kazakh herder and eagle hunter Asker and his wife Ahgul. What makes this family so special is that they have one son and five daughters. The oldest of which, together with the son, are also training to eagle hunters. This delightful family will be your hosts. We leave the visit flexible as this leads to a more natural experience but you’ll spend time living alongside the family in the stunning setting of their winter home. You'll experience their hospitality and their way of life as herders and eagle hunters, and learn more about the traditions and culture of the Mongol Kazakhs. Two days will be spent at the Altai Nomad Games. This eagle festival will provide you with a wealth of cultural experience as you mix in the company of small-town folk, herders and Mongol Kazakh eagle hunters. The festival is a celebration of Kazakh culture with traditional Kazakh games and horse races as well as competitions showcasing the relationship between hunter and eagles - focusing on the communication between them and the speed, agility and accuracy of the ‘berkut’ (the female Golden Eagle).

Ulgii: Travel to the provincial capital of Ulgii for your last night in western Mongolia. Here you will be hosted at the home of our Kazakh translator Jako and her family. Ulgii is a predominantly Kazakh city where a Muslim influence is widespread, from street signs to clothes and food, and gives the town its diverse atmosphere. As well as spending time at the home of Jako, do as the locals do and visit the market where you can always purchase some locally made embroidery crafts and take in the view from Ulgii’s viewpoint - always popular with local families. Also, consider the surprisingly interesting local museum.
ULAANBAATAR: Take a domestic flight back to Ulaanbaatar. The trip ends on the transfer back to your hotel although we provide advice and support.

tourName: Wild Mongolia & Golden Eagle Festival holiday
generalInfo: Revel in Mongolia’s beautiful mountainous regions, traverse the steppe and desert to discover ancient archaeological sites, stay with a nomadic family and witness the vibrant Golden Eagle Festival.

dayInfo.title: Ulaanbaatar.
dayInfo.description: We begin our adventure in Ulaanbaatar, a thriving city, where modern life comfortably blends with the Mongolian traditional lifestyle. Meet your Tour Leader and the rest of your group in the hotel lobby at 5pm for your Welcome Meeting.

dayInfo.title: Ulaanbaatar.
dayInfo.description: Today we explore the fascinating city of Ulaanbaatar and accustom ourselves to the Mongolian way of life.

dayInfo.title: Ulaanbaatar to Khovd.
dayInfo.description: We fly to Khovd city, the entry point to western Mongolia and the capical of the province. Khovd is the most ethnically diverse and distinct region of Mongolia and this is highlighted in the city which is rich in colourful museums, markets and diversity. We enjoy a city tour with our local guide.

dayInfo.title: To Zereg.
dayInfo.description: Today we drive c130km to Zereg. We will have a picnic lunch in the serene landscape on the way. On arrival we will meet our host camel herder family in the evening and spend time getting to know them.

dayInfo.title: Migration Day.
dayInfo.description: The family is moving to their winter camping ground by camel. We will help them to take down their ger, load the cargo and move with their nomadic herders to their next camping spot. After lunch we will assist with building the gers and marvel at the nomadic way of life.

dayInfo.title: To Khoid Tsenkher Cave.
dayInfo.description: Today we visit the expansive cave that has paintings depicting the ancient people who lived in the cave and their ways of life in umber and red ochre. The drawings date back to the 40.000 ago upper Paleolithic period, depicts animals such as stags, buffalo, oxen, ibex, lions, Argali sheep, antelopes, camels, elephants, ostriches, and mammoth.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Olgii.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast we drive to Olgii, the capital of Bayan-Olgii, Mongolia’s most western province. A region famous for its untouched snow-capped mountains and the Kazakh inhabitants that make up nearly ninety percent of Olgii’s population with their rich and unique culture.

dayInfo.title: Altai Mountains & Tavan Bogd National Park.
dayInfo.description: Today we journey into the spectacular mountains to visit some of the pristine lakes of the region. Dayan Lake is our first stop, considered by ornithologists to be of significant importance. The lake remains frozen from June to October but we may be lucky and spot a kestrel or falcon in the area. We will also visit the deer stones and balbal stones, 6-8th century Turkish burial markers. We will spend the evening wth our Kazakh nomadic family hosts.

dayInfo.title: Altai Mountains & Tavan Bogd National Park.
dayInfo.description: We spend the day enjoying the scenery around the shores of Lake Dayan. The landscape is stunning wtih forests and snow-capped mountains.

dayInfo.title: Altai Mountains & Tavan Bogd National Park.
dayInfo.description: Today we will travel further on some challenging roads, deep into the lakes region of Tavan Bogd National Park. The two main lakes, Khurgan Nuur and Khoten Nuur, some 1500-2000 years old, are fed by streams from the surrounding mountains with a number of stunning waterfalls. We will spend the night on Biluut Hill which is full of Turkic origin rock carvings. Everywhere we turn there are magnificent views and pristine scenery.

dayInfo.title: Altai Mountains & Tavan Bogd National Park.
dayInfo.description: Today we make our way to the White River Valley. The astonishingly beautiful valley and freshwayer might even be an opportunity to get your feet wet! We will also have an opportunity to visit Tuvan people, a separate ethnic and cultural group in Mongolia who still live a nomadic life and practice Shamanism.

dayInfo.title: Shiveet Uul Mountain.
dayInfo.description: Today we hike to the impressive Shiveet Uul Mountain with its beautiful blue lakes, 4000m high snow-capped summit, glacier and rich archaeological history.

dayInfo.title: Return to Olgii.
dayInfo.description: Today we drive back to Olgii and spend the afternoon discovering the city further and perhaps including some arts and crafts shopping.

dayInfo.title: Olgii and the Golden Eagle Festival.
dayInfo.description: Get set for a truly unique & unforgettable experience, one that is sure to be a highlight of our Wild Mongolia & the Golden Eagle Festival journey! Each year Kazakh hunters from near and far attend the festival with their prized Golden Eagles, known as Berkut, to enter them into competitions testing their speed, agility and accuracy. Ceremonies, dance performances and a parade in the city square take place in celebration of the Kazakh heritage and traditions.

dayInfo.title: Olgii and the Golden Eagle Festival.
dayInfo.description: The Golden Eagle festivities continue. Join the crowds, who are often as entertaining as the hunters themselves, in cheering the winners and serenading the losers in song!

dayInfo.title: To Khovd.
dayInfo.description: We return to Khovd for our flight home. On arrival in Khovd we have some time at leisure to reflect on the last few days of festivites.

dayInfo.title: Return to Ulaanbaatar.
dayInfo.description: We join our flight back to Ulaanbaatar to return to where this incredible journey began. On our final day in Ulaanbaatar we will enjoy an amazing performance by traditional throat singers.

dayInfo.title: Ulaanbaatar.
dayInfo.description: We say farewell to our fellow travellers and our journey comes to an end.

tourName: Zavkhan horse riding holiday in Mongolia
placesVisited: Ulaanbaatar, Karakorum, Erdene Zuu monastery, Terekhiin Tsagaan Nuur, the Great White Lake, Horse riding in Tarvagatai Uul National Park, Khar Nuur, Gandan Nuur, Eagle Festival in Ulgii for September departures
generalInfo:
Mongolia is a land of horses and horsemen. What better way to really experience it than on a horse riding holiday in Mongolia? This trek takes you far away from the main tourist areas, to remote Zavkhan Province.

Where We Travel:
This rarely visited area is a wonderful mix of steppe, forest, rivers, mountains and desert, populated by hardy nomadic herders. The riding is often said to be the best in the world - no fences, few roads, and terrain that allows you to gallop forever. Zavkhan sees almost no foreign visitors, and tourism has had no impact on the traditional way of life.

The Horses and Riding:
Experienced riders will love the local horses, small but fast and strong, and perfectly suited to the environment. However, the trek is also suitable for those with less experience - adventurous travelers who recognize that horseback is the ideal way to experience Mongolia.

We structure our treks so that experienced riders who dream of galloping across open steppe, like Genghis Khan on the war-path, can do so, while those of us who prefer a more gentle pace can take our time and enjoy the scenery. Even people with no riding experience at all are welcome to join us on our rides - we will make sure to look after you well.

At the end of each day we meet our 4WD support vehicles and set up camp. Zavkhan is an undeveloped region with no tourism infrastructure, so you will be wilderness camping during the trek. This is a rare opportunity to travel in a part of the country that has seen little change over the years. You will meet the local herders and experience their ancient way of life.

Why Trek With Us?
We have been arranging treks in this region for more than 10 years, working directly with our friends amongst the nomadic herders. The staff who accompany you are very experienced - most have been with us from the start. Our horse wranglers will teach you how to ride the Mongolian horses in a way that is exciting and safe.

During the trek you will be accompanied by an experienced English-speaking trip leader and our team of wranglers, drivers and cook. The trip leader will make sure you have the perfect horse to match your riding experience.

The Great Mongolian Road Trip:
We begin with an epic road trip to Zavkhan, an experience not to be missed. Mongolia's roads are notorious, but our sturdy Russian 4WD vehicles can handle anything. The drive takes us west across beautiful open steppe and forested hills, stopping at the ancient capital of Karakorum, arriving in Zavkhan after two and a half days. At the end of the trek we fly back to Ulaanbaatar (driving one way is enough for anyone!).

Naadam Festival add-on:
Before our 12th July trek, you may like to stay on for the annual Naadam Festival opening ceremony (11th July) in Ulaanbaatar, a spectacular celebration of Mongolian culture. Quite unlike any other festival in the world!

dayInfo.description: Arrive in Ulaanbaatar. Explore the monasteries and museums of this exotic city. The group will meet for our first dinner together in the evening.

Drive west to Karakorum, the site of the ancient capital of the Mongolian empire. Visit Erdene Zuu, a 16th-century monastery. Stay at a comfortable ger camp for the night (there's plenty of camping to come!)
Continue on to Terekhiin Tsagaan Nuur, the Great White Lake. There will be time for an evening hike amongst forested hills, before settling in at a cosy ger camp for the night.
Reach Zavkhan where we set up a riverside camp and meet the horses and our local wranglers. Your guide and wranglers will help select the ideal horse for you and show you how to ride Mongolian style!
A day ride through forested meadows to get to know your horse - and for your horse to get to know you.

Ride through steppe, forest and mountains of Tarvagatai Uul National Park. Every day is different as we travel deep in to this rarely-visited park. The pace is varied and suitable for all levels of riding experience - there will be plenty of opportunity for experienced riders to gallop until their eyes water! Less experienced riders will stay at a pace that they are comfortable with. Keep an eye out for elk and other elusive wildlife. We will be invited in to gers along the way to drink tea and eat various local delicacies with nomadic friends (Tip: you CAN say no when offered a particularly choice sheep's eyeball)
Khar Nuur, the desert lake, or Gandan Nuur, the forest lake. Swim, hike, or just relax and enjoy the spectacular scenery.
Fly back to Ulaanbaatar.
Transfers to airport
